question: Question_09_(c)
statement:
\emph{Each of the short-answer questions below is worth 5 points. Put
your answer in the box provided and show your work. No credit will be
given for the answer without the correct accompanying work.}

Express the limit

\begin{align*}\lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \ln\left(1 + \frac{k}{n}\right)\end{align*}

as a definite integral, and leave it in the form of an integral. Do not
evaluate it!
sols:
The Riemann sum formula using the right end points for a function $f(x)$
is

$f(x) = R_{n} = \sum_{k=1}^{n}f(x_{k})\Delta x$

where

$x_{k} = a + k\Delta x \quad\quad \Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n}$

In our example, comparing the terms, we see that

$\Delta x = \frac{1}{n}$

and so

$b-a = 1$

Also, we have that

$f(x_{k}) = \ln\left(1 + \frac{k}{n} \right)$

So taking $f(x) = \ln(1 + x)$, we have

$x_{k} = a + k\Delta x = a + \frac{k}{n} = \frac{k}{n}$

so we have $a=0$ and hence since $b - a  = 1$ and so $b = b - 0  = 1$.
Plugging all this information in, we have

\begin{align*}\lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \ln\left(1 + \frac{k}{n}\right) = \int_{0}^{1}\ln(1+x)\,dx\end{align*}

The Riemann sum formula using the right end points for a function $f(x)$
is

$f(x) = R_{n} = \sum_{k=1}^{n}f(x_{k})\Delta x$

where

$x_{k} = a + k\Delta x \quad\quad \Delta x = \frac{b-a}{n}$

In our example, comparing the terms, we see that

$\Delta x = \frac{1}{n}$

and so

$b-a = 1$

Also, we have that

$f(x_{k}) = \ln\left(1 + \frac{k}{n} \right)$

So taking $f(x) = \ln(x)$, we have

$x_{k} = a + k\Delta x = a + \frac{k}{n} = 1 + \frac{k}{n}$

so we have $a=1$ and hence since $b - a  = 1$ and so $b - 1  = 1$ giving
$b=2$. Plugging all this information in, we have

\begin{align*}\lim_{n \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{k=1}^{n} \ln\left(1 + \frac{k}{n}\right) = \int_{1}^{2}\ln(x)\,dx\end{align*}
